title: Brittany Ferries has teamed up with ORCA for Portsmouth whale cruises
text:
156 shares 3
View
comments
I went whale watching in Kaikoura, New Zealand, a few years ago and either saw three whales or the same one three times.
Now you don’t have to go to the other side of the world to experience these magnificent creatures. Brittany Ferries has teamed up with ORCA, Europe’s leading whale and dolphin conservation charity, for a series of mini-cruises to watch whales in the Bay of Biscay.
I have been enthralled by these epic mammals ever since interviewing Sir David Attenborough during a Save The Whale campaign.
Sarah Lucas took a trip on a Brittany Ferries boat to the Bay of Biscay for some whale-watching
I finished my radio piece with moving cries of the humpback whale. While humpbacks may be rare in the Bay of Biscay, a third of the 87 known species of whales and dolphins are found in European waters and Biscay is one of the best places to see them.
On the first cruise of the season, a group of about 60 of us left Portsmouth aboard the ferry Pont-Aven, heading for Santander. We were led by Richard Allcorn, a conservation biologist and teacher.

Share this article Share 156 shares From the observation deck we scanned, through binoculars, a silvery grey palette of sky and seas, while helpful ORCA volunteers pointed out what we should be seeing or had just missed.
Look out for ‘blows’ – a plume of water shooting up from a blow-hole, ‘splashings’, the white caps of waves breaking, and congregations of birds, like gannets.
‘Single dark fin, at 4 o’clock!’ bellowed a woman who’d clearly done this sort of thing before.
After two hours a group of pilot whales were sighted, their smurf-like dorsal fins identifying them – black stitches threading through the water.
Then dolphins flew joyously over the waves.
As well as whales, dolphins are likely to be spotted in the Bay of Biscay
Brittany Ferries has teamed up with ORCA, Europe’s leading whale and dolphin conservation charity, for a series of mini-cruises to watch whales
The ship sails across a range of habitats. Where the continental shelf gives way to the deep ocean the nutrients that swirl around attract pilot whales.
An hour away from Santander, deep canyons on the seabed harbour dolphins and fin whales, the largest after the prince of whales, the blue.
But Cuvier’s beaked whale holds the deep-sea diving record and can stay underwater for two hours. One of the places you’re most likely to see this scarce whale is from a ferry on the Bay of Biscay.
We stopped off in Santander for pinchos, the breadier relative of tapas, before heading back on board for a tally of what we’d seen and shot, mercifully just with cameras.
We’d spotted pilot, fin, minke and Cuvier’s beaked whales, striped, common and bottlenose dolphin, plus a basking shark.
Chris Packham, TV presenter and wildlife expert, will be on board Pont Aven for the last of this season’s whale spotting trips on September 22.
A whale of a time is guaranteed!
TRY YOUR HAND AT WHALE-WATCHING Brittany Ferries ( brittany ferries.com/whale , 0330 159 7000 quoting Y15WWC) offers the ‘Whale and Dolphin’ cruises to Spain.
They cost from £170pp and include crossings from Portsmouth to Santander and back to Plymouth with two nights cabin accommodation, expert whale watching and dolphin spotting advice and time ashore in Santander.
Further information: Orcaweb.org.uk .
